channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Yahya Sinwar Helped Start the War in Gaza. Now He’s Key to Its Endgame.
item.description: Hamas’s leader in Gaza is considered an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks that prompted Israel to retaliate. As mediators seek a cease-fire, a deal depends on Mr. Sinwar as well as his Israeli foes.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, center, Hamas’s leader in Gaza, in Gaza City last year. He is now believed to be hiding in a tunnel network in the enclave.

item.title: Ahead of Olympics, World Anti-Doping Agency Faces a Trust Crisis
item.description: Concerns are growing that the body whose job is keeping sports free of illegal drugs is failing at that mission, leading Congress to question U.S. support.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The World Anti-Doping Agency president, Witold Banka, has defended his organization’s handling of a doping case involving 23 Chinese swimmers.

item.title: Russian Forces Push Deeper Into Northern Ukraine
item.description: A Ukrainian military unit said that its troops were forced to retreat from several positions and that one settlement had been captured by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A person being evacuated to Kharkiv city on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Seaborne Grain Exports Bounce Back to Near Prewar Levels
item.description: The flow of grain ships through ports in the Odesa region is a welcome boost for Ukraine’s war-ravaged economy. But analysts warn it may not last.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 700-foot Liberian-flagged ship carrying corn bound for Bangladesh leaving the Ukrainian port of Odesa in March.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Fighting Rages in Northern Gaza, an Area Israeli Troops Had Left
item.description: The fighting in Gaza City and Jabaliya fit into a familiar scenario: Israeli forces returning to an area where they had defeated Hamas earlier in the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Controversy Over K-pop Band NewJeans
item.description: The firm Hybe has lost hundreds of millions of dollars in market value because of a feud with the creative force behind the band NewJeans.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Min Hee-jin, who developed the band NewJeans and is embroiled in a dispute with her employer, at a news conference last month in Seoul.

item.title: Bus Crash in Indonesia Kills 11, Including Students, After Graduation Celebration
item.description: The vehicle was carrying dozens of teachers and students when it sped out of control on a downhill road and crashed into several vehicles in a hilly resort area.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Police officers and rescuers inspecting the wreckage of a bus after a crash on Saturday in Subang, Indonesia.

item.title: Burkina Faso Accused of Massacring Civilians
item.description: Witnesses and human rights groups claim the West African country’s military killed more than 220 people, including women and children, in February. It was neither a mistake nor a one-off, they say.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Isolated and Defiant, Israel Vows to ‘Stand Alone’ in War on Hamas
item.description: As the death toll in Gaza has risen, countries have turned their backs on Israel. The consequences of those desertions, from security to economics, risk turning Israel into a pariah.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: On Friday, in a largely symbolic gesture, the United Nations General Assembly backed Palestine’s bid for U.N. membership.

item.title: British Colleges Are Handling Protests Differently. Will It Pay Off?
item.description: University leaders have so far adopted a more permissive attitude to pro-Palestinian encampments than their U.S. counterparts. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mary Turner
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cyclists and pedestrians pass a student encampment set up to protest Israel’s action in Palestine, on a lawn outside the Natural History Museum, at Oxford University on May 9.

item.title: Will an Authoritarian Government in Venezuela Allow a Fair Election?
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro has held on to power by holding sham elections. In July he will run again, but would he willingly cede power?
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: People line up to vote at an improvised voting center in a football court in Catia, a former stronghold of Nicolas Maduro’s party.

item.title: Flooding Kills Dozens in Afghanistan
item.description: Heavy seasonal rains have set off floods in the northern province of Baghlan and in at least three other provinces.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah, Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:description: Flash flooding in northern Afghanistan has killed more than 300 people, U.N. officials said.

item.title: Big, Smoggy Bangkok Gets a Badly Needed Breath of Fresh Air
item.description: In the heart of this megacity, an industrial site has been turned into an oasis for residents (and birds, bats and mosquito-eating dragonflies).
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trees and wetlands thrive in the newly expanded Benjakitti Park in central Bangkok, where a factory complex once churned out cigarettes.

item.title: Jacob Zuma, Once Leader of the A.N.C., Becomes Its Political Rival
item.description: Spurred by his anger at the African National Congress, Mr. Zuma formed his own political party and is gathering support among voters aggrieved by the failures of South Africa’s governing party.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Joao Silva
item.category: Spear of the Nation (MK) (South African Political Party)
item.media:description: Supporters of former South African president Jacob Zuma’s uMkhonto weSizwe Party (MK) protested over the lack of service delivery in Pietermaritzburg, KwaZulu_Natal province where they delivered a memorandum to the city’s mayor’s office, on Wednesday.

item.title: Mystery of Mona Lisa’s Location May Be Solved
item.description: A mash-up of geology and art history has identified a likely setting for one of the world’s most famous paintings.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: A geologist said the shape of the lake and the gray-white limestone in the background of Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa helped identify the setting of the portrait.

item.title: About 300,000 Gazans Have Fled Rafah, U.N. Says
item.description: The Israeli military has expanded its evacuation orders for Rafah, deepening fears that it was preparing a full-scale invasion of the city in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Tents housing displaced Palestinians in Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Can Parrots Converse? Polly Says That’s the Wrong Question.
item.description: In a cautious new paper, scientists tried to determine whether an interactive speech board might enrich the life of a parrot named Ellie.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Elon Musk’s Diplomacy: Woo Right-Wing World Leaders. Then Benefit.
item.description: Mr. Musk has built a constellation of like-minded heads of state — including Argentina’s Javier Milei and India’s Narendra Modi — to push his own politics and expand his business empire.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Jack Nicas and Alex Travelli

item.title: As Israel Steps Up Attacks, 300,000 Gazans Are Forced to Evacuate
item.description: Many say there is nowhere to go, and even the “humanitarian zone” recommended by Israel is neither safe nor equipped to handle all of them, the U.N. says.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Bilal Shbair, Aaron Boxerman and Ben Shpigel
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Fleeing Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Saturday. Around 150,000 have left Rafah in the past week, after the Israeli military ordered an evacuation.

item.title: Russian Attacks Open a New Front in Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s latest offensive has expanded the battlefield along Ukraine’s northern border, and sent thousands of civilians fleeing to Kharkiv, the closest large city.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: Olha Melnichuk, an 85-year-old resident of Liptsi, near the Russian border, was evacuated to a shelter in Kharkiv, the country’s second-largest city, on Saturday.

item.title: When Travel Plans Go Awry
item.description: There are ways of keeping ourselves anchored, even when we enter a parallel universe disconnected from time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada’s Public Sector Unions Threaten Disruption Over Return to Office
item.description: After their strike last year failed to win the right to work remotely, the unions are challenging a plan calling for three days a week at workplaces.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Return to office was a major issue during last year’s public service walkout.

item.title: South Africa Again Asks the ICJ to Order Israel to Withdraw From Rafah
item.description: The “very survival” of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip is under threat, South Africa said.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Naledi Pandor, South Africa’s foreign minister, left, and the South African ambassador to the Netherlands, Vusimuzi Madonsela, at the International Court of Justice at The Hague, in January.

item.title: Northern Lights Photos: Aurora Borealis Lights Up the Night Sky
item.description: The unusual sight of aurora borealis was visible around the world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The northern lights flared in the sky over a farmhouse in Brunswick, Maine.

item.title: What We Know About Where Aid Can Enter Gaza
item.description: A look at the humanitarian assistance getting into the Gaza Strip by land, air and sea.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Trucks waiting to go into Gaza on a road blocked by a protest on Thursday.

item.title: Kuwaiti Emir Dissolves Parliament for Up to Four Years
item.description: The country’s ruler also suspended several constitutional articles, raising concerns that he could diminish political freedoms in one of the Middle East’s few semi-democratic states.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Members of the Kuwaiti Parliament in Kuwait City in January. On Friday, the emir, Sheikh Mishal Al Ahmed Al Sabah, announced that he would suspend Parliament and several articles of the Constitution.

item.title: Northern Lights Forecast: How to See the Aurora Borealis This Weekend
item.description: The Space Weather Prediction Center said solar activity would be high again on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Northern lights hung over the Lofoten Islands in Norway in March.

item.title: Aiming for Rosier Ties, Xi Wraps Up Europe Visit
item.description: The red carpet receptions China’s leader received in France, Serbia and Hungary helped recast a strained relationship with the continent.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Vivien Cher Benko
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary in Budapest on Thursday.

item.title: Cease-Fire Talks Hit Snag Over Hostages and Permanence, Officials Say
item.description: Representatives of Israel and Hamas have left Egypt without any deal in sight.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Families and supporters of hostages march Wednesday in Tel Aviv, calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to make a deal to free their loved ones.

item.title: U.S. Defends U.N. Voting ‘No’ on Palestinian Membership
item.description: The United States among a handful of holdouts on the vote, which was widely seen as a rebuke of the Americans and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: John F. Kirby, a national security spokesman, briefing reporters at the White House on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Criticizes Israel Over Conduct in Gaza
item.description: In a report, the State Department avoids sweeping conclusions but raises the prospect that Israel may have violated humanitarian laws.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Biden ordered a State Department report on Israel’s use of American weapons and compliance with humanitarian law.

item.title: Israel and Egypt Spar, Squeezing Gaza Aid Routes
item.description: With no resumption of deliveries in sight, officials fear the territory’s threadbare humanitarian relief effort could collapse altogether.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Ronen Bergman and Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Palestinians lined up for food in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Friday. A virtual cutoff in humanitarian aid is threatening to devolve into famine if shipments are not quickly restored.

item.title: U.S. Military’s Plea to Israel: Do More to Protect Gazans in War Zone
item.description: The Biden administration says it is still waiting to see a detailed plan for how Israeli forces plan to evacuate civilians from the city of Rafah.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The United States wants Israel to move Palestinian civilians in Rafah out of the way, and to do more to help humanitarian aid get in, before launching any incursion into the city.

item.title: Actions by Israel and Egypt Squeeze Gaza Aid Routes
item.description: Israel’s military has seized and closed the Rafah crossing as it fights in the area, and officials say that Egypt is not allowing aid trucks to go to the other main crossing at Kerem Shalom.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Trucks loaded with aid for Gaza are lined up in El Arish, Egypt, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Global Lesson from Britain’s Crumbling Conservative Party
item.description: Sometimes, even as the far right rises, the center holds.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, Leader of the Labour Party, right, and Mayor Claire Ward of the East Midlands, celebrating at a post election rally in Mansfield, England, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. to Announce New Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles
item.description: The administration could raise tariffs on electric vehicles from China to 100 percent in an attempt to protect American auto manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Lorenz Huber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration is expected to raise tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles in order to protect domestic manufacturers.

item.title: People Leaving Rafah Describe Fearful Flight From Israeli Assaults
item.description: ‘We feel depressed and so exhausted from repeating the same suffering,’ one mother of 11 said.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly Votes to Back Palestinian Membership Bid
item.description: The vote comes after the United States last month vetoed a Security Council measure granting full U.N. membership to a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: A United Nations General Assembly vote to declare that Palestinians qualify for full-member status was approved, 143 to 9, with 25 nations abstaining.

item.title: U.N. officials warn that aid efforts face imminent threat from lack of fuel and food.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: An employee with fuel tanks at Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al Balah in the central Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Satellite Images Reveal Where Russian Nuclear Weapons Could Be Stored in Belarus
item.description: A New York Times analysis shows security upgrades unique to Russian nuclear storage facilities at a Cold War-era munitions depot.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl
item.media:credit: The New York Times, Source: Maxar Technologies

item.title: From Ancient Charcoal, Hints of Wildfires to Come
item.description: By digging into the geologic record, scientists are learning how wildfires shaped — and were shaped by — climate change long ago.
item.dc:creator: Laura Poppick

item.title: Biden Is Not the First U.S. President to Cut Off Weapons to Israel
item.description: Other presidents, including, Ronald Reagan, used the power of American arms to influence Israeli war policy. But the comparisons underscore how much the politics of Israel have changed over the years.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan used the power of American arms several times to influence Israeli war policy, at different points ordering warplanes and cluster munitions to be delayed or withheld.

item.title: Russia Mounting New Border Assaults in North, Ukraine Says
item.description: Armored columns tried to punch through at several points, the military said, raising pressure on already stretched Ukrainian forces.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Fighting a fire on Friday after an overnight strike in Kharkiv. Russia has stepped up its bombardment of the northern Ukrainian city in recent weeks.

item.title: An English Town Drops Apostrophes From Street Signs. Some Aren’t Happy.
item.description: The move has prompted some resistance, with someone writing an apostrophe on a sign for St. Mary’s Walk. “What’s next?” one North Yorkshire resident asked. “Commas?”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs
item.media:description: Using a marker, someone drew an apostrophe onto a new street sign that had omitted it.

item.title: What Did P.S.G.’s Money Buy?
item.description: The club’s superstar era cost billions and upended European soccer. But after another Champions League failure and Friday’s confirmation that Kylian Mbappé will leave, what was it all for?
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: How Pro-Palestinian Students Pushed Trinity College Dublin to Divest
item.description: A surge of attention hit Ireland’s most prestigious university over protests that involved Israel, Gaza and the famed medieval Book of Kells.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Students at Trinity College Dublin staging a campus protest against Israel’s actions in Gaza last Saturday. The students said they were inspired by similar movements in the United States.

item.title: Kherson Residents Rebuild and Brace for New Russian Attack
item.description: The people of the Kherson region have slowly rebuilt their homes and livelihoods since a Ukrainian counteroffensive forced out Russian troops. Now they are bracing for another Russian attack.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: After Her Sister Wed at 11, a Girl Began Fighting Child Marriage at 13
item.description: Memory Banda’s battle, which she has been waging since she was a teenager in a village in Malawi, started with a poignant question: “Why should this be happening to girls so young?”
item.dc:creator: Rabson Kondowe
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Amos Gumulira for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memory Banda’s activism against child marriage began in a small village in Malawi she was just 13.

item.title: How a Remote Australian Town Nearly Ran Out of Food
item.description: Many isolated Indigenous communities are dependent on fragile supply chains. This year, floods made that dramatically clear.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The road to Lajamanu in the Northern Territory in Australia.

item.title: UK Shakes Off Recession as Economy Grows Faster Than Expected
item.description: Gross domestic product increased 0.6 percent in the first quarter, after shrinking the two previous quarters.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Customers shopping at a record store in London. Consumer spending has been a key aspect of Britain’s economic resilience.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles near the border with Gaza.

item.title: U.S. Ship Carrying Aid for Gaza Departs From Cyprus
item.description: A Pentagon spokesman said bad weather had made it impossible to install a new floating pier and causeway.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: The container ship Sagamore, right, docked in Cyprus on Wednesday.

item.title: UNRWA Says It Closed East Jerusalem Headquarters After Fire and Attacks
item.description: The leader of the agency said the fire had caused extensive damage, but that no staff had been injured.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: A demonstration outside the UNRWA offices in the West Bank in March.

item.title: Japanese American Civil Rights Group Pushes for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The call for a truce followed months of pressure from younger members who believed the group had a duty to stand up for Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Inoue, the executive director of the Japanese American Citizens League, next to a painting that depicts a Supreme Court case during the World War II incarceration of people of Japanese descent.

item.title: Chad’s Military Ruler Is Announced as Winner of Disputed Election
item.description: The Central African country’s incumbent president and his prime minister both ran. Shortly after the prime minister claimed victory, the president was declared the winner.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: President Mahamat Idriss Déby of Chad at a campaign rally in Ndjamena, the capital, last week.

item.title: Bernard Pivot, Host of Influential French TV Show on Books, Dies at 89
item.description: For 15 years, French viewers watched Mr. Pivot on his weekly show, “Apostrophes,” to decide what to read next.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Bernard Pivot in 1980. His weekly show, “Apostrophes,” ran from 1975 to 1990.

item.title: As Gaza Talks Falter, Negotiators Look for a Deal or a Scapegoat
item.description: President Biden’s decision to withhold offensive weapons if Israel attacks Rafah has scrambled cease-fire talks. But much of the various sides’ recriminations may be to gain advantage — or shift blame.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden has long objected to an assault on Rafah, where more than one million Palestinians have taken refuge, because he has seen no war plan that would not result in extensive civilian casualties.

item.title: Rafah Invasion Tests Biden’s Relationship With Israel
item.description: Defiant Israelis have vowed to do “whatever is necessary” in the Gaza Strip despite the American president’s threat to withhold weapons.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles near the border of the Gaza Strip on Thursday at an undisclosed location.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Stormy Daniels, Day Two
item.description: Also, Israel-Hamas talks falter again.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Stormy Daniels, 45, leaving court yesterday.

item.title: Israel ‘Smashing Into Rafah’ Will Not Eradicate Hamas, Biden Aide Says
item.description: The president has grown increasingly wary of a major assault in the densely populated city in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: Smoke rising over buildings after an airstrike near Rafah, southern Gaza, on Tuesday.
